qas.question: What is the Judaeo-German language developed by Ashkenazi Jews who migrated to Central Europe?
What is the Judaeo-Spanish language developed by Sephardic Jews who migrated to the Iberian peninsula?
Name one reason the ancient and distinct Jewish languages have largely fallen out of use?

answers.text: Jewish exodus from Arab and Muslim countries

qas.question: For how long have Jews not spoken the local languages of the regions they migrated to?

plausible_answers.text: the local or dominant languages of the regions they migrated to

qas.question: What language was developed by Ashkenazi Jews who migrated to the Iberian peninsula?
What was not a factor in Jewish languages falling out of use?
What is a Jewish language that has not fallen out of use?

context: For <b3_0>centuries<b3_0/>, Jews worldwide have spoken <b4_0>the local or dominant languages of the regions they migrated to<b4_0/>, often developing distinctive dialectal forms or branches that became independent languages. <a0_0><b5_0>Yiddish<b5_0/><a0_0/> is the Judæo-German language developed by Ashkenazi Jews who migrated to Central Europe. <a1_0>Ladino<a1_0/> is the Judæo-Spanish language developed by Sephardic Jews who migrated to the Iberian peninsula. Due to many factors, including the impact of the Holocaust on European Jewry, the <a2_0>Jewish exodus from Arab and Muslim countries<a2_0/>, and <b6_0>widespread emigration<b6_0/> from other Jewish communities around the world, ancient and distinct Jewish languages of several communities, including <b7_0>Judæo-Georgian<b7_0/>, Judæo-Arabic, Judæo-Berber, Krymchak, Judæo-Malayalam and many others, have largely fallen out of use.
